name: MB-6880 / Basic Master and Basic Master Level 2
keyboard: QWERTY full-stroke keyboard. JIS standard. 56 keys.
price: Basic Master :118000 yensBasic Master Level 2 : 228000 yens
description:
This early japanese computer seems quite strong with its metal case. The machine has a very sober look. The keyboard is minimalist too, no CTRL or ESC keys...

There is apparently no graphical high-resolution but the computer offers 253 predefined characters including graphic symbols.

The power switch is placed on the front case just above the keyboard.

The Basic Master eventually evolved into the Basic Master Level 2 which offered more memory (8k instead of 4k, wow).

(1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is nearly a stupid scan ! <br><br> The young boy says : ''In 1984, my father bought me a MO-5" <br> And on his desk is a 1998 calendar... <br><br> They meant that if you bought the MO-5 then (the advert is from 1984), you would be rich and clever 14 years later (in 1998). Ha ha ha !! <br><br> It's funny to see how they tried to represent an office and a town of 1998. I really love this one !  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JULY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"access to the Forth power" <br><br> "with the Jupiter Ace, enjoy profesionnal experience of Forth"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Maxi Basic Yeno SC 3000 : program at full gallop"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> As the American magazine 'Byte' commented, "for some time to come the 1040STF will be the clear leader in price/performance." </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (MAY 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> The ATOM -a definitive personal computer. Simple-to-build, simple-to-operate. But a really powerful full-facility computer. And designed on an expandable basis. You can buy a superb expanded package now-tailored to your needs. Or, you can buy just the standard Atom kit, and, as you grow in confidence and knowledge, add more chips. No need to replace your equipment. No need to worry that your investment will be overtaken by new technology. As you need more power, more facilities, you can add them! <br><br> <b>The standard ATOM kit includes:</b><br> . Full sized QWERTY keyboard. Rugged polystyrene case<br> . Fibreglass PCB. 2K RAM. 8K ROM. 23 integrated circuits . Full assembly instructions including tests for fault-finding. (Once built, connect it to any domestic TV and power source)<br> . Power requirement: 8V at 800 M A. ATOM power unit available.<br> PLUS FREE MANUAL written in two sections <br> - teach yourself BASIC and machine code for those with no knowledge of computers, and a reference section giving a complete description of the ATOM's facilities. All sections are fully illustrated with example programs.<br><br> <b>The ATOM concept</b><br> Adding chips into sockets on the PCB allows you to progress in affordable steps to large-scale expansion. You can see from the specifications that the RAM can be increased to 12K allowing high resolution (256 x 192) graphics. Two further ROM chips, e.g. maths functions, can be added directly to the board giving a 16K capacity. In addition to 5 I/O lines partly used by the cassette interface, an optional VIA device can provide varied I/O and timer functions and via a buffer device allow direct printer drive. An optional module provides red, green and blue signals for colour. An in-board connector strip takes the ATOM communications loop interface. Any number of ATOMs may be tinked to each other - or to a master system with mass storage, hard copy facility. Interface with other ACORN cards is simplicity itself. Anyone ACORN card may be fitted internally. So you can see there are a vast number of modular options and additions available, expanding with your ability and your budget.<br><br> <b>The ATOM hardware includes:</b><br> .Memory from 2K to 12K RAM on board (up to 35K in case)<br> .8K to 16K ROM (two 4K additions) 86502 processor<br> .Video Display allows high resolution (256 x 192) graphics and red, green and blue output<br> .Cassette Interface-CUTS 300 baud<br> .Loudspeaker allows tone generation of any frequency<br> .Channel36 UHF Modulator Output .Bus output includes internal connections for Acorn Eurocard.<br><br> <b>The ATOM software includes:</b><br> .32-bit arithmetic (+/- 2,000,000,000)<br> .High speed execution<br> .43 standard/extended BASIC commands <br> .Variable length strings (up to 256 characters)<br> .String manipulation functions<br> .27 32-bit integer variables<br> .27 additional arrays<br> .random number function .PUT and GET byte<br> .WAIT command for timing<br> .DO-UNTIL construction<br> .Logical operators (AND, OR, EX-OR)<br> .LINK to machine-code routines<br> .Plot draw and move. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Paul Durrant</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Speed serves business.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Most small system users think all microcomputers are created aqual. And they're right. If you want performance, convenience, styling, high technology and reliability (and who doesn't?) your micro usually has a price tag that looks mote like a mini. It seems big performance always means big bucks. But not so with the SuperBrain...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (NOV. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says that 37 cartridges are already available and that a BASIC programming cartridge is on the way (though it will never make it to the shelves). <br><br> The advert also clearly says that the system comes from America and that it offers Arcade Hits at home.</blockquote>
